questions.stem: A neurologist explains to a patient that a disease is destroying the cells responsible for producing myelin in the brain and spinal cord. Which type of glial cell is being destroyed?

options.text: Schwann cells
Astrocytes
Oligodendrocytes
Microglia

questions.explanation: Oligodendrocytes produce myelin in the central nervous system (CNS), which includes the brain and spinal cord. Schwann cells produce myelin in the peripheral nervous system (PNS). Astrocytes regulate the blood-brain barrier and extracellular environment. Microglia serve as the brain's immune cells. This CNS vs. PNS myelin-producing cell distinction is high-yield for the EPPP.

questions.stem: During an action potential, what event directly triggers the release of neurotransmitters from synaptic vesicles into the synaptic cleft?

options.text: Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels at the terminal button
Influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels at the terminal button
Efflux of potassium ions during repolarization of the axon terminal
Activation of the sodium-potassium pump at the presynaptic membrane

questions.explanation: When the action potential arrives at the terminal button, voltage-gated calcium (Ca2+) channels open, allowing calcium influx. This calcium triggers synaptic vesicles to fuse with the presynaptic membrane and release neurotransmitters via exocytosis. Sodium channels are involved in propagating the action potential along the axon, not directly in neurotransmitter release. Potassium efflux is part of repolarization. The sodium-potassium pump restores resting potential.

questions.stem: A patient taking an antipsychotic medication develops involuntary choreiform movements (tardive dyskinesia). Which dopamine pathway's blockade is most directly responsible for this motor side effect?

options.text: Mesolimbic pathway
Mesocortical pathway
Nigrostriatal pathway
Tuberoinfundibular pathway

questions.explanation: The nigrostriatal pathway projects from the substantia nigra to the striatum and is responsible for motor control. Blockade of dopamine receptors in this pathway by antipsychotics produces extrapyramidal symptoms including tardive dyskinesia. The mesolimbic pathway (VTA to nucleus accumbens) is associated with positive symptoms of schizophrenia. The mesocortical pathway (VTA to prefrontal cortex) relates to negative/cognitive symptoms. The tuberoinfundibular pathway regulates prolactin release.

questions.stem: A behavioral genetics researcher reports that the heritability of a trait is 0.75 in the population studied. Which of the following is the MOST accurate interpretation of this finding?

options.text: 75% of any individual's expression of this trait is determined by their genes
75% of the variance in this trait within the studied population is attributable to genetic differences among individuals
Environmental factors can account for no more than 25% of this trait in any given individual
The trait cannot be significantly modified by environmental intervention

questions.explanation: Heritability (h-squared) estimates the proportion of variance in a trait within a population that is attributable to genetic differences. It applies to populations, not individuals. Option A is the most common error -- heritability does not tell us how much of an individual's trait is genetic. Option C misapplies population-level statistics to individuals. Option D is incorrect because even highly heritable traits can respond to environmental intervention (e.g., IQ gains from enriched environments).

questions.stem: A genetically extraverted adolescent seeks out social activities and party environments that further reinforce their sociability. This best illustrates which type of gene-environment correlation?

options.text: Passive gene-environment correlation
Evocative (reactive) gene-environment correlation
Active gene-environment correlation (niche-picking)
Gene-environment interaction (GxE)

questions.explanation: Active gene-environment correlation (niche-picking) occurs when individuals actively select environments that match their genetic predispositions. The extraverted adolescent choosing social environments is a classic example. Passive rGE occurs when parents provide both genes and a matching environment (e.g., musical parents providing instruments). Evocative rGE occurs when genetically influenced traits elicit responses from others. GxE interaction refers to the gene's effect on phenotype depending on the environment, which is a distinct concept.

questions.stem: Select ALL mechanisms by which neurotransmitter action is terminated at the synapse.

options.text: Reuptake of the neurotransmitter into the presynaptic neuron via transporter proteins
Enzymatic degradation of the neurotransmitter in the synaptic cleft
Diffusion of the neurotransmitter away from the synapse
Reversal of the action potential direction to reabsorb the neurotransmitter
Increased firing of the sodium-potassium pump to neutralize the neurotransmitter

questions.explanation: There are three primary mechanisms for terminating neurotransmitter action: (1) reuptake -- the neurotransmitter is transported back into the presynaptic neuron (this is the target of SSRIs, SNRIs, and other reuptake inhibitors); (2) enzymatic degradation -- enzymes break down the neurotransmitter in the cleft (e.g., acetylcholinesterase breaks down ACh, MAO breaks down monoamines); (3) diffusion -- the neurotransmitter drifts away from the synapse. Action potentials do not reverse direction, and the sodium-potassium pump restores resting potential but does not neutralize neurotransmitters.

questions.stem: Select ALL statements that are TRUE about the all-or-none law of neural firing.

options.text: An action potential either fires at full amplitude or does not fire at all
The intensity of a stimulus is coded by the frequency of firing (rate coding)
A stronger stimulus produces a larger amplitude action potential
The number of neurons activated also codes stimulus intensity
During the absolute refractory period, a sufficiently strong stimulus can still trigger an action potential

questions.explanation: The all-or-none law states that action potentials fire at full amplitude or not at all -- there is no partial action potential (A is correct). Stimulus intensity is coded by firing rate (B) and the number of neurons recruited (D), not by action potential amplitude. Option C is incorrect because action potential amplitude is constant regardless of stimulus strength. Option E is incorrect because during the absolute refractory period, no stimulus of any strength can trigger another action potential; only during the relative refractory period can a stronger-than-normal stimulus elicit firing.

questions.stem: Select ALL neurotransmitters that are correctly paired with their primary clinical association.

options.text: Dopamine deficit in the nigrostriatal pathway -- Parkinson's disease
Acetylcholine deficit -- Alzheimer's disease
GABA excess -- anxiety disorders
Serotonin deficit hypothesis -- major depression
Glutamate excess (excitotoxicity) -- neuronal death in stroke

questions.explanation: A, B, D, and E are all correctly paired. Dopamine deficit in the nigrostriatal pathway causes Parkinson's motor symptoms. ACh deficit is associated with Alzheimer's disease (treated with cholinesterase inhibitors). The serotonin deficit hypothesis is a major model of depression (basis for SSRI treatment). Excessive glutamate causes excitotoxicity and neuronal death during stroke and TBI. Option C is incorrect because anxiety disorders are associated with GABA deficits (not excess) -- benzodiazepines treat anxiety by enhancing GABA activity.

questions.stem: Select ALL findings that would constitute evidence for a genetic contribution to a psychological disorder using the twin study method.

options.text: Monozygotic (MZ) concordance rate is substantially higher than dizygotic (DZ) concordance rate
MZ twins reared apart show high concordance for the disorder
MZ concordance is 100% for the disorder
DZ concordance rate is approximately half of MZ concordance rate
Adopted children resemble their biological parents more than their adoptive parents on the trait

questions.explanation: A is correct: substantially higher MZ than DZ concordance implicates genetic factors. B is correct: MZ twins reared apart provide the strongest evidence for genetic influence since similarity cannot be attributed to shared rearing environment. D is correct: since DZ twins share approximately 50% of segregating genes vs. 100% for MZ, a DZ rate roughly half the MZ rate is consistent with additive genetic effects. C is incorrect because 100% MZ concordance would actually suggest complete genetic determination, which is exceedingly rare and the question asks about evidence for genetic contribution, not determination. E describes adoption study methodology, not twin study methodology.

questions.stem: Select ALL accurate statements about epigenetic mechanisms.

options.text: Epigenetic changes alter gene expression without changing the underlying DNA sequence
DNA methylation is one mechanism by which environmental factors can turn genes on or off
Some epigenetic changes can be transmitted across generations
Epigenetic modifications are permanent and irreversible once established
Early maternal care in rats has been shown to produce epigenetic changes in glucocorticoid receptor genes that affect stress reactivity

questions.explanation: A, B, C, and E are all accurate. Epigenetics involves changes in gene expression without altering DNA sequence (A). DNA methylation and histone modification are key mechanisms (B). Some epigenetic changes show transgenerational inheritance (C). Meaney's research demonstrated that maternal licking/grooming in rats produced epigenetic changes in glucocorticoid receptor genes, affecting lifelong stress reactivity (E). Option D is incorrect -- epigenetic changes can be reversible, which is part of what makes them clinically significant as potential therapeutic targets.

questions.stem: Match each neurotransmitter with the substance that acts as its specific agonist or enhancer.
questions.explanation: Nicotine is an acetylcholine agonist that binds to nicotinic ACh receptors. Morphine is an endorphin/opioid receptor agonist that mimics endogenous opioids. Benzodiazepines are GABA-A receptor positive allosteric modulators that enhance the inhibitory effects of GABA. SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) increase serotonin availability by blocking its reuptake into the presynaptic neuron, effectively enhancing serotonergic transmission.

questions.stem: Match each dopamine pathway with its primary clinical association when dysfunctional.

columns.text: Motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease; extrapyramidal side effects
Positive symptoms of schizophrenia; reward and addiction
Negative symptoms and cognitive deficits in schizophrenia

questions.explanation: The mesolimbic pathway (VTA to nucleus accumbens) is involved in reward and motivation; hyperactivity is linked to positive symptoms of schizophrenia and addiction. The mesocortical pathway (VTA to prefrontal cortex) supports executive function; hypoactivity is linked to negative symptoms and cognitive deficits. The nigrostriatal pathway (substantia nigra to striatum) controls motor function; degeneration causes Parkinson's and blockade causes extrapyramidal side effects. The tuberoinfundibular pathway (hypothalamus to pituitary) inhibits prolactin; blockade causes hyperprolactinemia.

questions.stem: Select ALL correct associations between each glial cell type and its functions. Multiple functions may apply to each cell type.

columns.text: Serve as the brain's immune cells

questions.explanation: Astrocytes regulate the blood-brain barrier, maintain the extracellular environment, and modulate synaptic transmission. Oligodendrocytes produce myelin in the CNS -- this is the cell type destroyed in multiple sclerosis. Schwann cells produce myelin in the PNS. Microglia are the brain's resident immune cells, removing debris and responding to infection or injury. The distinction between oligodendrocytes (CNS myelin) and Schwann cells (PNS myelin) is a frequently tested EPPP point.

questions.stem: Select ALL correct associations. Each neurotransmitter may have multiple clinical associations.

columns.text: Primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain
Involved in excitotoxicity and NMDA receptor-mediated long-term potentiation
Deficit is associated with Alzheimer's disease

questions.explanation: GABA is the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain; deficit is associated with anxiety and seizures, and benzodiazepines enhance its action. Glutamate is the primary excitatory neurotransmitter; excessive glutamate causes excitotoxicity (neuronal death in stroke and TBI), and NMDA receptors are critical for long-term potentiation (LTP) in learning and memory. Acetylcholine deficit is a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease, treated with cholinesterase inhibitors. Norepinephrine hyperactivity is implicated in PTSD and the exaggerated arousal response.

questions.stem: The resting membrane potential of a neuron is approximately {{blank1}}. When excitatory inputs depolarize the membrane to the threshold of approximately {{blank2}}, voltage-gated {{blank3}} channels open first during the depolarization phase. The all-or-none law states that stimulus intensity is coded not by the amplitude of individual action potentials but by the {{blank4}} of firing.

options.text: -70 mV
-55 mV
+40 mV
-90 mV
-70 mV
-55 mV
+30 mV
-80 mV
potassium (K+)
calcium (Ca2+)
sodium (Na+)
chloride (Cl-)
amplitude
frequency
duration
wavelength

questions.explanation: The resting potential is approximately -70 mV, maintained by the sodium-potassium pump. Threshold is approximately -55 mV. During depolarization, voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels open first, allowing rapid Na+ influx that drives the membrane potential toward +30 to +40 mV. The all-or-none law dictates that stimulus intensity is coded by firing frequency (rate coding) and the number of neurons activated, not by action potential amplitude, which remains constant.

questions.stem: In the synaptic cleft, an {{blank1}} mimics or enhances the action of a neurotransmitter, while an {{blank2}} blocks or reduces its action. SSRIs treat depression by blocking the {{blank3}} of serotonin, thereby increasing its availability. The process by which action potentials 'jump' between nodes of Ranvier on myelinated axons is called {{blank4}}.

options.text: agonist
antagonist
inverse agonist
reuptake inhibitor
agonist
antagonist
prodrug
partial agonist
enzymatic degradation
receptor binding
reuptake
synthesis
continuous conduction
saltatory conduction
retrograde transmission
graded conduction

questions.explanation: An agonist mimics or enhances neurotransmitter action (e.g., nicotine is an ACh agonist). An antagonist blocks or reduces neurotransmitter action (e.g., curare blocks ACh receptors). SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) block the transporter that removes serotonin from the synaptic cleft, increasing its availability. Saltatory conduction refers to action potentials jumping from one node of Ranvier to the next along myelinated axons, increasing speed up to 120 m/s.

questions.stem: A 68-year-old patient presents with progressive memory loss, confusion, and difficulty with activities of daily living. A neurologist diagnoses probable Alzheimer's disease and prescribes donepezil. Consider the neurochemical basis of this presentation and treatment approach.

options.text: Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert
Loss of acetylcholine in cortical and hippocampal regions
Excess dopamine in the mesolimbic pathway
Overactivation of GABAergic inhibitory circuits
Acetylcholine deficit underlying cognitive and memory impairment
Serotonin excess causing hippocampal hyperactivation
Norepinephrine depletion causing motor symptoms
Cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil) prevent breakdown of ACh, increasing its availability at synapses
Treatment provides symptomatic improvement but does not halt the neurodegenerative process
Dopamine agonists would be the first-line pharmacological treatment
GABA antagonists would restore normal memory function

questions.explanation: Alzheimer's disease involves degeneration of cholinergic neurons, particularly in the nucleus basalis of Meynert, leading to acetylcholine deficits in cortical and hippocampal regions critical for memory. Donepezil is a cholinesterase inhibitor that prevents the enzymatic breakdown of ACh by acetylcholinesterase, thereby increasing its availability at synapses. This provides symptomatic improvement in cognition and function but does not modify the underlying neurodegenerative disease course. Dopamine agonists are used for Parkinson's, not Alzheimer's.

questions.stem: A researcher studying identical twins separated at birth finds a concordance rate of 48% for schizophrenia in the monozygotic twin pairs. Consider the implications of this finding for understanding the genetic and environmental contributions to schizophrenia.

options.text: Genetic factors make a substantial contribution to schizophrenia risk
Environmental factors also play a significant role since concordance is well below 100%
Schizophrenia is entirely genetically determined since MZ twins share 100% of DNA
Shared family environment is the primary cause since twins were raised apart
Schizophrenia has high heritability (~0.80) with important non-genetic contributions
Schizophrenia is primarily caused by shared environmental factors
The concordance rate proves that genetics play no meaningful role
Gene-environment interactions likely contribute to why not all genetically vulnerable individuals develop the disorder
Epigenetic mechanisms may help explain why genetically identical individuals can differ in disease expression
Preventive environmental interventions are impossible given the high genetic loading
Adoption into any family environment would guarantee disease development

questions.explanation: The 48% MZ concordance rate for schizophrenia in twins reared apart provides strong evidence for genetic contribution (since similarity cannot be attributed to shared environment). However, the concordance is well below 100%, demonstrating that genetic vulnerability alone is insufficient -- environmental factors, gene-environment interactions, and epigenetic mechanisms all contribute to whether the disorder manifests. Heritability for schizophrenia is estimated at ~0.80. Importantly, high heritability does not mean the disorder is inevitable or unmodifiable -- environmental interventions remain relevant.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are scientifically accurate about neuron structure and function.
questions.passage: A neurophysiology review states the following: [Dendrites are the primary input structures of the neuron, receiving signals from other neurons]. Furthermore, [the axon receives incoming signals and transmits them to the dendrites of the same neuron]. The review continues: [the myelin sheath dramatically increases conduction speed through saltatory conduction at the nodes of Ranvier]. It also notes that [microglia produce myelin in the central nervous system, while Schwann cells produce myelin in the peripheral nervous system]. Additionally, [the sodium-potassium pump maintains resting potential by pumping 3 Na+ out and 2 K+ in]. Finally, [during hyperpolarization, the membrane potential briefly overshoots below resting potential before returning to -70 mV].

highlightableSegments.text: Dendrites are the primary input structures of the neuron, receiving signals from other neurons
the axon receives incoming signals and transmits them to the dendrites of the same neuron
the myelin sheath dramatically increases conduction speed through saltatory conduction at the nodes of Ranvier
microglia produce myelin in the central nervous system, while Schwann cells produce myelin in the peripheral nervous system
the sodium-potassium pump maintains resting potential by pumping 3 Na+ out and 2 K+ in
during hyperpolarization, the membrane potential briefly overshoots below resting potential before returning to -70 mV

questions.explanation: Segments 1, 3, 5, and 6 are accurate. Dendrites do receive signals (primary input structures). Myelin does increase conduction speed via saltatory conduction. The Na+/K+ pump does pump 3 Na+ out and 2 K+ in. Hyperpolarization does overshoot to ~-80 mV before returning to -70 mV. Segment 2 is incorrect because the axon conducts signals AWAY from the soma toward terminal buttons, not toward dendrites. Segment 4 is incorrect because OLIGODENDROCYTES (not microglia) produce myelin in the CNS.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that correctly describe principles of behavioral genetics.
questions.passage: A behavioral genetics textbook states: [Heritability estimates apply to populations, not to individuals -- one cannot say 80% of a person's IQ is genetic]. It also claims that [a highly heritable trait cannot be influenced by environmental intervention, making treatment futile]. The text explains that [nonshared environment accounts for more variance in personality and psychopathology than shared environment]. Another passage states that [in passive gene-environment correlation, children inherit both genes and a matching environment from their parents]. The textbook further claims that [if MZ twin concordance is 100%, this definitively proves the trait is entirely genetic with no environmental influence]. Finally, it notes that [the Caspi et al. study on the 5-HTTLPR gene and depression is a classic example of gene-environment interaction].

highlightableSegments.text: Heritability estimates apply to populations, not to individuals -- one cannot say 80% of a person's IQ is genetic
a highly heritable trait cannot be influenced by environmental intervention, making treatment futile
nonshared environment accounts for more variance in personality and psychopathology than shared environment
in passive gene-environment correlation, children inherit both genes and a matching environment from their parents
if MZ twin concordance is 100%, this definitively proves the trait is entirely genetic with no environmental influence
the Caspi et al. study on the 5-HTTLPR gene and depression is a classic example of gene-environment interaction

questions.explanation: Segments 1, 3, 4, and 6 are correct. Heritability applies to populations, not individuals. Nonshared environment (sibling-specific experiences) accounts for more variance than shared (family-wide) environment in personality/psychopathology (Plomin & Daniels, 1987). Passive rGE involves children inheriting both genes and matching environments from parents. The Caspi et al. (2003) 5-HTTLPR study is a classic GxE example. Segment 2 is incorrect: even highly heritable traits can be modified by environment. Segment 5 is incorrect: 100% MZ concordance could also be explained by identical environments; further, MZ twins share prenatal environment, which is also environmental.

questions.stem: Arrange the steps of synaptic transmission in the correct chronological sequence, from the arrival of the action potential to the termination of neurotransmitter action.

items.text: Action potential arrives at the terminal button
Voltage-gated calcium channels open, allowing Ca2+ influx
Synaptic vesicles fuse with the presynaptic membrane (exocytosis)
Neurotransmitter molecules are released into the synaptic cleft
Neurotransmitter binds to postsynaptic receptors, producing EPSPs or IPSPs
Neurotransmitter action is terminated by reuptake, enzymatic degradation, or diffusion

questions.explanation: Synaptic transmission follows a precise sequence: (1) The action potential arrives at the terminal button. (2) This depolarization opens voltage-gated calcium channels, and Ca2+ flows into the terminal. (3) The calcium influx triggers synaptic vesicles to fuse with the presynaptic membrane. (4) Neurotransmitter molecules are released into the synaptic cleft via exocytosis. (5) These molecules bind to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane, producing excitatory (EPSPs) or inhibitory (IPSPs) postsynaptic potentials. (6) Neurotransmitter action is terminated by reuptake, enzymatic degradation, or diffusion.

questions.stem: Arrange the phases of the action potential in the correct temporal sequence.

items.text: Resting potential is maintained at approximately -70 mV by the sodium-potassium pump
Excitatory inputs depolarize the membrane to threshold (~-55 mV)
Voltage-gated Na+ channels open; rapid Na+ influx depolarizes toward +30 to +40 mV
Na+ channels inactivate; voltage-gated K+ channels open, allowing K+ efflux (repolarization)
K+ channels remain open briefly, causing hyperpolarization (~-80 mV)
Sodium-potassium pump restores resting ion concentrations; membrane returns to -70 mV

questions.explanation: The action potential proceeds in a strict sequence: (1) Resting state at -70 mV. (2) Excitatory inputs bring the membrane to threshold (-55 mV). (3) Depolarization: Na+ channels open, Na+ rushes in, membrane potential peaks. (4) Repolarization: Na+ channels inactivate, K+ channels open, K+ flows out. (5) Hyperpolarization: K+ channels stay open briefly, overshooting to ~-80 mV. (6) The sodium-potassium pump restores ion gradients and the membrane returns to resting potential.

questions.stem: A neuroscience researcher measures the heritability of IQ across different age groups in the same population.
questions.question: What pattern does this data demonstrate, and what is the best explanation for this trend?

options.text: Heritability decreases with age because environmental influences accumulate over time
Heritability increases with age, likely due to increasing active gene-environment correlation (niche-picking) as individuals gain more autonomy
Heritability remains stable across the lifespan, as genes are fixed at conception
Heritability peaks in childhood when parental influence is strongest and declines thereafter

questions.explanation: The data shows that heritability of IQ increases across development -- a well-replicated finding in behavioral genetics. The primary explanation is that active gene-environment correlation (niche-picking) becomes increasingly important with age as individuals gain more autonomy over their environments. Children have less control over their environments, so shared environment plays a larger role. As people mature, they increasingly select environments that match their genetic predispositions, amplifying genetic influence on the phenotype.

questions.stem: A pharmacologist measures synaptic serotonin levels and depressive symptom severity in a patient starting SSRI treatment over several weeks.
questions.question: What does this data suggest about the relationship between serotonin reuptake blockade and clinical improvement?

options.text: Serotonin increases and symptom relief occur simultaneously and immediately after SSRI initiation

Serotonin levels increase rapidly after SSRI initiation, but clinical improvement in depressive symptoms is delayed by several weeks, suggesting downstream neuroadaptive changes are necessary for therapeutic effect
Depressive symptoms improve before serotonin levels increase, suggesting a placebo effect
Neither serotonin nor symptoms change meaningfully, indicating SSRIs are ineffective

questions.explanation: The data demonstrates a well-established pharmacological phenomenon: SSRIs increase synaptic serotonin levels rapidly (within days of initiation), but clinical improvement in depressive symptoms is delayed by 2-6 weeks. This dissociation suggests that the simple increase in serotonin availability is not sufficient for therapeutic effect. Rather, downstream neuroadaptive changes -- including receptor downregulation, changes in gene expression, neuroplasticity, and neurogenesis -- are likely required for the antidepressant effect to manifest.

questions.stem: Categorize each substance or drug as primarily an agonist, antagonist, or reuptake inhibitor for its target neurotransmitter system.

items.text: Nicotine (ACh system)
Curare (ACh receptors)
Fluoxetine/Prozac (serotonin system)
Morphine (endorphin/opioid receptors)
Naloxone (opioid receptors)
Methylphenidate/Ritalin (dopamine and norepinephrine systems)

questions.explanation: Agonists mimic or enhance neurotransmitter action: nicotine activates nicotinic ACh receptors, and morphine activates opioid receptors. Antagonists block or reduce neurotransmitter action: curare blocks ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction (causing paralysis), and naloxone blocks opioid receptors (reversing opioid overdose). Reuptake inhibitors block the transporter that removes neurotransmitter from the synapse: fluoxetine (an SSRI) blocks serotonin reuptake, and methylphenidate blocks dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake.

questions.stem: Categorize each research finding or concept as an example of gene-environment interaction (GxE), gene-environment correlation (rGE), or neither.

items.text: Individuals with the short 5-HTTLPR allele develop depression only after experiencing stressful life events
Musically gifted parents pass on music genes AND provide a home full of instruments and lessons
An extraverted teenager seeks out parties and social groups matching their temperament
A genetically irritable child elicits harsh discipline from parents, worsening behavioral problems
Phenylketonuria (PKU) causes intellectual disability only when phenylalanine is present in the diet
Down syndrome (trisomy 21) causes intellectual disability regardless of environmental conditions

questions.explanation: Gene-environment interaction (GxE) occurs when the effect of a gene depends on the environment: the 5-HTTLPR/stress/depression finding (Caspi et al., 2003) and PKU (genetic vulnerability expressed only with dietary phenylalanine) are classic examples. Gene-environment correlation (rGE) occurs when genetic factors influence environmental exposure: passive rGE (musical parents providing instruments), active rGE/niche-picking (extraverted teen seeking social environments), and evocative rGE (irritable child eliciting harsh parenting). Down syndrome causes disability regardless of environment, representing a predominantly genetic effect.
